sections.title: Animation
sections.description: D3’s [data join](https://d3js.org/d3-selection/joining), [interpolators](https://d3js.org/d3-interpolate), and [easings](https://d3js.org/d3-ease) enable flexible [animated transitions](https://d3js.org/d3-transition) between views while preserving [object constancy](https://bost.ocks.org/mike/constancy/).

sections.title: Interaction
sections.description: D3’s low-level approach allows for performant incremental updates during interaction. And D3 supports popular interaction methods including [dragging](https://d3js.org/d3-drag), [brushing](https://d3js.org/d3-brush), and [zooming](https://d3js.org/d3-zoom).

sections.title: Analysis
sections.description: D3 is for more than visualization; it includes tools for quantitative analysis, such as [data transformation](https://d3js.org/d3-array), [random number generation](https://d3js.org/d3-random), [hexagonal binning](https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-hexbin), and [contours via marching squares](https://d3js.org/d3-contour).

sections.title: Hierarchies
sections.description: D3 supports [hierarchical data](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy), too, with popular layouts such as [treemaps](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy/treemap), [tidy trees](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy/tree), and [packed circles](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy/pack). And you retain complete control over how the data is displayed.

sections.title: Networks
sections.description: D3 works with networked data (graphs), including [simulated forces](https://d3js.org/d3-force) for resolving competing constraints and an iterative [Sankey layout](https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-sankey).

sections.title: Bars
sections.description: D3 [scales](https://d3js.org/d3-scale) and [axes](https://d3js.org/d3-axis) support basic charts. Or invent a new form that better serves your needs.

sections.title: Lines
sections.description: With direct control over [graphics](https://d3js.org/d3-shape), and support for both SVG and Canvas, the possibilities are endless.

sections.title: Areas
sections.description: Go beyond basic area charts with [difference charts](/d3/difference-chart) or [streamgraphs](/d3/streamgraph). [Ridgeline plots](/d3/ridgeline-plot) and [horizon charts](/d3/horizon-chart) are great for comparing many simultaneous time series.

sections.title: Dots
sections.description: Don’t forget the humble scatterplot. For a single dimension, consider the [beeswarm](/d3/beeswarm); for finding pairwise dimensional correlations, try a [SPLOM](/d3/splom).

sections.title: Radial
sections.description: Pies and donuts are good for comparing a part to the whole. And radial layouts can be appropriate for cyclical data.

sections.title: Annotation
sections.description: Labels, legends, axes, titles, guides, and keys help a visualization communicate effectively. Here are a few strategies.

sections.title: Maps
sections.description: D3 implements a dizzying array of [geographic projections](https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-geo-projection). It works great with [GeoJSON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GeoJSON), [TopoJSON](https://github.com/topojson), and even [shapefiles](/d3/streaming-shapefiles).

sections.title: Essays
sections.description: Weave interactive visualizations seamlessly into prose for explorable explanations. Don’t just *tell* the reader something; let the reader see, engage, and ask questions.

sections.title: Just for fun
sections.description: Why not have a little fun? Life’s not just about work, you know.
